Persevere through hatred and persecution, for that is when the blessing is promised.

bhtAttempts.bht: If you are separate from society or the Church because of your faith, you are blessed. Being cast out or excommunicated may be hard, but it is for the sake of righteousness and for the Son of man's sake. Jesus, who is fully human and fully divine, strongly identifies with all people, regardless of race, age, or culture. This identification makes his humanity unique and demands a divine explanation. The name Christian, disciple, or Nazarene may even become contemptuous and stigmatized, but remember that Jesus himself often referred to himself as the Son of man. Enduring rejection and persecution for Christ's sake is when the blessing is promised.

Being separate or cast out from society or the Church because of your faith can be challenging, but it signifies a blessed state. This expulsion could encompass both excommunication and social isolation. By identifying as a Christian, disciple, or Nazarene, you may face contempt and stigma, as Jesus himself often did by referring to himself as the Son of man. Enduring hatred and persecution for the sake of Christ is when the promised blessing is realized, as it is for righteousness and the Son of man's sake.

To be separate and cast out from society or the Church is not limited to Jewish excommunication but extends to all forms of expulsion. Despite the contempt and stigma that may be associated with identifying as a Christian, disciple, or Nazarene, you are blessed. This blessedness is connected to righteousness and the Son of man, as Jesus, the archetypal man, aligned the cause of righteousness with the acceptance of Himself.
